SENT.plain: Electrical field distributions of event-related potentials (ERP's) were recorded during an auditory "oddball paradigm" and were analyzed in terms of time and space
Fourteen normal subjects and 14 chronic patients were cerebral thrombosis were studied

For the components N1 and P3 of the ERP's to target stimuli, reference-independent measures (latency, global field power, location of maximal or minimal potential, and location of centroids) were determined
Stroke patients displayed P3 abnormalities in latency, amplitude, and electrical field on the scalp
In addition, N1 electrical fields were also abnormal

These ERP abnormalities correlated significantly with the extent of mental function impairment in the stroke patients, and they improved after administration of a cerebral metabolic enhancer (Nefiracetam: DM-9384)
The ERP's seemed to be sensitive in indicating the effects of the drug

These data suggest that time-course analysis of the spatial distribution of the ERP electrical field might be useful for evaluation of the extent of mental function impairment and the efficacy of drugs
